message.content:
We must “build” the cost‐item that appears on an income statement from the cost side of sales. In our chart many transactions are “Sales” which, aside from the revenue amounts, include a “cost_amount” that is assumed to be the cost of goods sold for that sale. (Other types – expense, purchase, fixed asset – are not to be “added” here because purchases end up being “allocated” to cost only when a sale is made.) 

Looking at each “Sale” row we pick out the “cost_amount” – then we add them up.

For example, the first sale row (id “Sale20240102003”) shows cost_amount = 50,000.00; the next “Sale20240102004” has cost_amount = 150,000.00; and so on. (For each row the “cost_amount” is provided as a column.) 

Step‐by‐step (grouping in order):

1. Sale20240102003: 50,000.00  
2. Sale20240102004: 150,000.00 → subtotal = 200,000.00  
3. Sale20240103006: 80,000.00 → subtotal = 280,000.00

Thus, by summing up the “cost_amount” from all sale transactions we obtain a final total cost of 5,240,000.00.

Therefore, in the income statement the “Total Cost” item becomes 5240000.00.
